utterance: GG: So I have a question that is perhaps a little more fundamental. So in the context of trying to actually capture CO2 from air, there is the entropic contribution, which is, you know, trying to bind the CO2 to the surface, and then there is the entropic contribution where we can effectively engineer a substrate so we can, you know, lock the CO2 molecule into that particular pore space. In the context of direct air capture, how important are entropic contributions? Like in terms, you know, in terms of the energetic input, should we even, does it even make sense for us to think about engineering materials for an entropic capture point of view, or does it simply make sense for us to just think about trying to engineer the enthalpic component of it? That is, so I wasn't sure what the current thinking is along those lines.

annotations.ask clarifying question: GG asks for clarification on the importance of entropic contributions in direct air capture and whether material engineering should focus on entropic or enthalpic components.
annotations.explain or define term or concept: GG explains the concept of entropic contribution in CO2 capture, both in terms of binding to a surface and engineering a substrate to lock the molecule.

utterance: CJ: I think the conventional wisdom in the literature thus far has focused on enthalpy because it is more straightforward and tractable. I think there is good science to be done by looking at the entropic contributions, and I think that area is less explored.

annotations.provide_supporting_evidence: CJ supports their point by mentioning the conventional wisdom in the literature focuses on enthalpy.
annotations.explain_or_define_term_or_concept: CJ explains that the focus has been on enthalpy because it is more straightforward and tractable.
annotations.present_new_idea: CJ suggests that good science can be done by looking at entropic contributions, an area less explored.

utterance: JM: Yeah, I mean, I think you pay a really large entropic penalty, right, for CO2 going from being free in the gas phase to confined on a surface. And so if you can do anything by inducing an increase in the entropy of a material when it binds CO2 to kind of compensate for that, then you can, you know, favor the absorption of more CO2 and potentially higher capacities at these lower partial pressures. But like Chris said, I think it is a very unexplored kind of area. It's less obvious to me. I mean, usually enthalpy and entropy of absorption should be quite highly correlated, just the more strong of a binding site you have for the gas, the more constrained it's going to be on the surface. And so there's usually not that much you can really do, which is why maybe it makes sense just to focus on binding energy because the entropy is just going to kind of tag along. But that's where I think if you have more dynamic absorbents or absorbents and things that respond and are not just inert materials, but actually change in terms of their dynamics or structure as a function of CO2 partial pressure, then you open up opportunities for thinking about engineering entropy.

annotations.expand on existing idea: JM expands on GG and CJ's discussion of enthalpy vs. entropy in CO2 capture by describing the entropic penalty of CO2 absorption and suggesting that dynamic absorbents could offer opportunities for engineering entropy.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: JM supports his claims by explaining that a stronger binding site leads to more constraint on the surface and that enthalpy and entropy of absorption are usually highly correlated.
annotations.explain or define term or concept: JM explains the concept of entropic penalty in CO2 absorption and how it relates to binding energy and surface constraint.

utterance: GG: Thank you.

annotations.acknowledge contribution: GG acknowledges JM and CJ's responses to their question about entropic contributions in CO2 capture.

utterance: CJ: I think a lot of classical absorbents, if you go to textbooks, right, are solid rigid materials where the entropy of absorption on the surface at different sites is not terribly different. But a lot of the dynamic materials, whether it be the the the moths that you're familiar with, Jared, from your past history or solid ionic liquid hybrids, supported liquid phases, polymeric structures that have chain mobility, those are all things where you can engineer the entropic term such that you have very different entropies of absorption.

annotations.expand on existing idea: CJ expands on his previous statement about enthalpy-focused conventional wisdom by contrasting classical absorbents with dynamic materials and their entropic properties.
annotations.explain or define term or concept: CJ explains the concept of entropy of absorption on the surface of classical absorbents versus dynamic materials.
annotations.acknowledge contribution: CJ acknowledges Jared's familiarity with moths in the context of dynamic materials.

utterance: GG: So from a big idea basic energy science point of view, does it make sense for us to start thinking a little bit more systematically about how we can engineer or if there are limits to that entropic term, what might those limits be? If there are correlations, obvious correlations with respect to enthalpy, what might those relationships look like? Are there limits in terms of performance in these unconventional solvent absorbent type systems that we can now start to quantify or maybe try to get a handle on? I think it seems like a rich area for computations as well as for experiments.

annotations.propose decision: GG proposes that the group should start thinking more systematically about how to engineer the entropic term in CO2 capture and explore its limits and correlations with enthalpy, especially in unconventional systems.

utterance: PD: Yeah, and we discussed something yesterday, and I think what you're talking about, you know, trying to literally distinguish materials, maybe, you know, through food screening or machine learning, materials which will have, you know, more entropic contribution or enthalpy. We can literally distinguish between them by running, you know, a lot of simulations as well. So this can also come in to guide some of the initial experiments, and then maybe, you know, experiments can guide the similar theory again. You know, that has to be a cycle, right? That has to be a cycle to refine it. So that is a very interesting route, and something, you know, I would agree. Basic energy point of view, definitely, you know, really appealing. Can I ask a question based on that? Because a lot of the computational material screening for separations that I'm familiar with leverages the fact that people work with primarily crystalline materials that allows for this high throughput screening to be more effective. utterance: PD: but somewhere combining those two will be, I would say, really, really great to for a problem like this because it is my understanding with a lot of these different kind of materials, just one method just simply does not do justice to the problem. utterance: CJ: I think we have about 15 minutes left and I want to try one other idea to stir some some different thinking. Um, you know, in a lot of engineered systems, you have control over temperature, pressure, other parameters. One of the challenging things about direct air capture is, you know, we're we're stuck with, um, 400 ppm, uh, CO2. But one of the things I haven't seen discussed a lot is if you imagine deploying direct air capture in different places around the world, you can imagine having conditions that range from, say, minus 20 to 40 degrees C. So if you were asked to try to do something with CO2 at 400 ppm at minus 20 degrees C, how would you think about doing that differently from, you know, the ambient conditions that we're normally used to thinking about indoors, 25 degrees C, you know, 30% relative humidity. And similarly, if you were designing, uh, a process that could operate in, you know, Oman in the middle of summer, you know, you you might be dealing with 35, 40 degrees C, uh, ambient temperatures. Um, so I just throw that out there as a way to maybe stir different ideas. This is a challenge where we're going to probably have 10 or 20 or 50 solutions that might be customized to different locations around the globe. So, would you change your way of thinking if you were stuck working at minus 10 C or or 40 C? So I'll just throw that out there as a possible question.

annotations.present new idea: CJ introduces the idea of considering varying temperatures in different geographical locations for direct air capture, which hasn't been discussed extensively.
annotations.explain or define term or concept: CJ explains the challenge of direct air capture, specifying the constraint of 400 ppm CO2 and contrasting varying temperature conditions (-20°C to 40°C) with standard ambient conditions (25°C, 30% relative humidity).
annotations.encourage particpatioin: CJ encourages the group to think differently about direct air capture by posing a question about how they would approach the challenge at different temperatures (-10°C or 40°C).

utterance: GG: Chris, my short answer to that is absolutely yes. So we've been looking at pathways to couple direct air capture with carbon mineralization, specifically with the intent of trying to produce carbonates. And one way to do that is to use conventional sorbents that are cheap. So you could use amino acid solvents like sodium glycine or even MEA. And so you have a high concentration of carbonate ions that you can now react with your calcium or magnesium, produce calcium, magnesium carbonate, have sufficiently high hydroxyl ions, so you can regenerate your solvent. So you have for a one pot process with internal recycling, internal pH swinging. So that's so that really drives down the cost of capture and mineralization, but it needs higher temperatures because of the thermodynamics of CO2 absorption because you're trying to couple absorption and crystallization. This is a process that would not work in very cold climates. Like if you're trying to do this in the Arctic, there simply is not going to be enough thermodynamic driving force for that. Uh there are other approaches to couple mineralization. So for example, again, if you're trying to feed CO2 to an algae pond, depends again where that algae pond is going to be located, if it's going to be located in a temperate region versus in a really cold climate. So cold climate is a real challenge and I am not entirely sure what subset of solutions can be deployed there. But if you but I do think there are a set of solutions that can be deployed in more temperate and tropical regions. Uh so that's my two cents on the thinking and we do a lot of thinking around this space, so I'd be very keen on hearing what we can actually do in really cold regions.

annotations.confirm decision: GG confirms CJ's suggestion to consider different temperature ranges for carbon capture.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: GG explains that coupling direct air capture with carbon mineralization needs higher temperatures due to thermodynamics.
annotations.expand on existing idea: GG expands on CJ's idea by suggesting solutions customized to different locations and temperatures.
annotations.present new idea: GG presents the idea of coupling direct air capture with carbon mineralization to produce carbonates using conventional sorbents.
annotations.explain or define term or concept: GG explains a process involving amino acid solvents, carbonate ions reaction with calcium/magnesium, and solvent regeneration.
annotations.ask clarifying question: GG asks for ideas on solutions for carbon capture in cold regions.

utterance: JM: I think from the perspective of like microporous absorbents, I think it's probably actually the opposite for just conventional absorption processes and that colder climates are probably a lot easier than um hotter climates just in that um in designing you can design binding sites that have much lower affinities for CO2 and still be able to achieve very high selectivities just because um there's less thermal energy available. So the boltzmann distribution is going to favor CO2 going to um you don't need as large of a delta E between different gas molecules to drive a lot of CO2 um into a material. It's the regeneration piece though that that's less clear to me exactly how that changes. I think selectivity and capacity are a lot easier. Um you can have weaker binding sites. Um but whether or not that actually leads to benefits on the regeneration side when you're already colder, um I have to think a little bit more about. I guess if you're in a cold climate but you had some geothermal heat source or something readily available then you um that might offer a lot of advantages.

annotations.expand on existing idea: JM expands on CJ's idea about how temperature affects CO2 capture by focusing on the impact of colder climates on microporous absorbents.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: JM explains that weaker binding sites can achieve high selectivities in colder climates due to the lower thermal energy and Boltzmann distribution.
annotations.ask clarifying question: JM questions how regeneration changes in colder climates despite the advantages for selectivity and capacity.

utterance: XS: Yeah, actually, I I I think that for electrochem, um it's a it's a really good question because I don't think it has it has been considered too much. So, um, we might have to change the whole architecture to have something that is um basically not solvent dependent. Like hopefully it's all immobilized and everything is just ionic, um, without like a flowing solvent. Um, so that's a really good question, actually. That's a really good, um, context for electrochemist to explore. I don't know if ionic liquids might be the best electrolyte then because they're they have a bigger range at a version can. I don't know what their phase transition is.

utterance: GG: If you're going to form carbonates, you really want to form calcium carbonate or magnesium carbonate because they're the least soluble and they'll drop out of your solution pretty quickly. If you try to form, you know, sodium carbonate, bicarbonate, potassium, group one carbonates, they still tend to stick around. In which case, you need to do an anti-solvent crystallization approach where you'd want to use ethanol to precipitate out a more soluble salt. So there are ways to work around it. The challenge really is this low solubility of CO2 in water in general. So there are ways to accelerate that, then that can, I think that would really address the challenge related to ocean capture too.

annotations.provide_supporting_evidence: GG provides a chemical explanation of why calcium and magnesium carbonates are preferred for carbon capture due to their low solubility and ease of removal from solution.

annotations.present_new_idea: GG introduces the idea of accelerating CO2 solubility in water to address challenges in ocean capture, a concept not previously discussed in detail.
